Microfabrics and zircon U-Pb (SHRIMP) chronology of high- and low-temperature 
mylonites from the Patos shear zone (Borborema Province, NE Brazil) 

 

Luís Gustavo F. Viegas1, 2,*, Carlos J. Archanjo1, Maria Helena B. M. Hollanda1, Alain 

Vauchez2  

 

1. Instituto de Geociências, USP, Rua do Lago 562, 05508-080 São Paulo, SP, Brazil 

2. Géosciences Montpellier, Place E. Bataillon 34095, Montpellier Cedex 5, France 

 

* Corresponding author. Email address: lgviegas@usp.br; present address: Instituto de 

Geociências, USP, Rua do Lago 562, 05508-080 São Paulo, SP, Brazil. 

Phone: +55 11 30 91 42 16 (L. G. Viegas). 

 

Keywords: Mylonite, microstructure, EBSD, Borborema Province, geochronology, NE Brazil 

 

Abstract 

 

 Microstructures and U-Pb SHRIMP zircon ages were used to constrain the fabric evolution 
and timing of mylonitisation in the Patos shear zone (NE Brazil). Melt-bearing HT-mylonites display 
solid-state fabrics with coarse quartz ribbons and sutured grain boundaries. K-feldspar is often 
fractured and shows peripheral myrmekite. The textures typically become magmatic at the contacts 
with anatexites. Zircons from two samples of the neosome show Palaeoproterozoic (~ 2.2 Ga) 
inherited cores that are enveloped by homogeneously recrystallised Neoproterozoic rims. These 
zircons define a discordia with lower intercept ages of 558 and 562 Ma but with large analytical 
errors. A leucogranite with transitional contacts with the host diatexites provides a well-constrained 
zircon mean age of 566 ± 5 Ma, which is considered to be the best estimate for the peak metamorphic 
conditions. The transition from the HT-mylonites to the fine-grained mylonites and ultramylonites is 
marked by progressive grain size reduction that is assisted by recrystallisation. Quartz CPOs display 
[0001] concentrations between Z and Y. The K-feldspar and plagioclase fabrics record the activity of 
the (010)[001] and (010)[100] slip systems and, in the lower-temperature tectonites, the (100)[010] 
slip system. Zircons from an ultramylonitic granite are very discordant but yield a well-defined lower 
intercept age of 545 ± 14 Ma. These results suggest a diachronic evolution in which an initial HT 
northern domain deformed by intracrystalline slip and melt-assisted granular flow and was followed 
by medium- to low temperature solid-state creep at the southern shear zone domain. This later event 
corresponds with the localisation of deformation along shear corridors, probably during exhumation 
of the structure. 
 

1. Introduction 

 

 The Neoproterozoic Brasiliano/Pan-African orogeny produced an anastomosing, wide 

network of conjugate shear zones across an area of 200000 km2 in Hoggar, 

Nigeria/Cameroon (Africa) and in the Borborema Province (NE Brazil). This type of 



Capítulo 5 – Cronologia de eventos e localização da deformação em zonas de cisalhamento dúcteis 
heterogêneas 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

68 

transcontinental fault system is believed to be typical of mid- to upper continental crustal 

deformation during large strike-slip movements. In the Borborema Province, ductile shear 

zones are associated with widespread granitic plutonism and synkinematic anatexis (Fig. 1; 

Vauchez et al. 1995). The interplay between magmatism and deformation resulted in the 

formation of > 20 km wide high-grade zones in which solid-state fabrics are observed in 

high-temperature mylonitic orthogneisses, migmatites and granites. Detailed field, structural 

and geochronological studies (Neves et al. 1996; Neves et al. 2000) have shown that 

magmatic activity played a major role in the nucleation and localisation of strain in these 

large shear zones and acted as a weak rheological layer that accommodated strain during 

strike-slip shearing. 

 Nevertheless, low-temperature mylonitic belts have been documented in several shear 

zones in the Borborema Province (Vauchez and Egydio-Silva 1992; Davison et al. 1995; 

Hollanda et al. 2010). These zones are composed of distinct fine-grained mylonites to 

ultramylonites that often form narrow zones or, in some cases, such as in the Patos shear 

zone, define abrupt contacts with high-temperature coarse mylonite belts (Corsini et al. 

1991). Structural and geochronological investigations in some shear zones have shown that 

these low-temperature corridors record late-stage strain localisation. 

 The Patos shear zone consists primarily of high-temperature mylonites that can be 

divided into three structural domains. The Central Domain, which includes the study area, is 

composed of E-trending mylonitic orthogneisses that, further west towards the Western 

Domain, envelope a duplex structure consisting of NE-trending lenses of orthogneisses, 

metapelites and granitoids (Corsini et al. 1996). In the Eastern Domain, near the Atlantic 

coast, the mylonites gradually rotate from E-W to NE-SW. The foliations are mainly 

subvertical, and stretching lineations are subhorizontal along the entire zone, which is 

consistent with a dominant transcurrent dextral motion (Corsini et al. 1991). Geophysical 

studies have shown that the Patos shear zone connects with the NE-trending Senador Pompeu 

shear zone beneath the Parnaíba basin and forms a branched shear zone system that was 

active in the Neoproterozoic (Oliveira 2008). 

 Recent anisotropy of magnetic susceptibility (AMS) studies in the migmatites (Viegas 

et al. 2013) showed that the partially molten material flows laterally along the strike of the 

structure, which agrees with the dextral shear sense of the zone. However, despite being the 

subject of extensive work for more than fifteen years (Archanjo et al. 2008 and references 

therein), little is known about the strain patterns involved in the shearing, particularly with 



Microestruturas e tramas cristalográficas na zona de cisalhamento patos  

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 69 

respect to the mechanisms of strain localisation and the chronology of the high- and low-

grade mylonite belts. This contribution focuses on the microstructures, crystallographic 

preferred orientations (CPOs) and zircon U-Pb (SHRIMP) analyses to investigate the fabric 

development and age of mylonitisation in the Patos shear zone. We present the first direct age 

determinations of synkinematic migmatisation and late fault reactivation using punctual 

methods. The roles of partial melting and strain localisation are addressed with respect to the 

evolution of a continental-scale strike-slip shear zone in which relatively short-lived (~30 

Ma) tectonic events occurred in a single kinematic framework. 

 

                          
Fig. 1: The Neoproterozoic Borborema shear zone system in NE Brazil. The small box shows the study area, 
which is located within the Patos shear zone.  
 

2. Geological setting 

 

The Patos shear zone consists of a ~ 600 km long strike-slip shear zone that deforms 

the Precambrian rocks of the Borborema Province (Fig. 1). In the Central Domain, located at 

the junction between the Patos shear zone and the Seridó Belt, anatexites occur within a ~ 30 

km wide connection zone. They are composed of stromatic metatexites, nebulitic diatexites 

and partially molten leucogranites (Viegas et al. 2013). Unpublished U-Pb and Sm-Nd data 

indicate that these anatexites derive from melting of the Palaeoproterozoic basement (Costa 

2002). A narrow medium- to low-temperature mylonite belt forms the southern margin of the 

shear zone (Fig. 2) and reworked the coarse mylonites and migmatites of the northern border 



Capítulo 5 – Cronologia de eventos e localização da deformação em zonas de cisalhamento dúcteis 
heterogêneas 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

70 

at low temperatures. Recent structural and geochronological studies south of the Patos shear 

zone have shown that some E-trending transcurrent structures record late-stage strain 

localisation (Hollanda et al. 2010). This is demonstrated in the Coxixola shear zone, in which 

A-type granite plutons and dikes were emplaced in a strain field that combined dextral shear 

and extension. U-Pb (SHRIMP) zircon ages in these sheared granites suggest that the 

Coxixola fault developed between 550 and 530 Ma (Hollanda et al. 2010). 

In the Patos mylonites, zircons dated by U/Pb (TIMs) (Costa 2002; Monié et al. 1997) 

showed strong disturbance but provided unconstrained upper intercept ages between 2.2 to 

2.0 Ga. 40Ar/39Ar plateau ages in amphibole, muscovite and biotite range from 540 Ma to 490 

Ma and were attributed to cooling of the shear zone (Corsini et al. 1998). Similar 40Ar/39Ar 

plateau ages were documented in muscovite from the Coxixola mylonites; the ~ 510 Ma age 

was attributed to the final uplift and exhumation of the shear zone (Hollanda et al. 2010). 

 

              
Fig. 2: Main geological units of the Patos shear zone at the intersection with the Seridó belt. Red arrows in the 
anatexites and contoured stereograms represent magnetic lineation measurements and main orientations, 
respectively. Kamb density contours, lower hemisphere.  
 

3. Rock types and shear zone structures 

 

 The Patos mylonites share a common orthogneiss/granite protolith and can be divided 

into four main rock types based on grain size, mesoscale structure and melt content: i) high-

temperature melt-bearing mylonites that are located in the northern (upper) part of the shear 

zone; ii) sheared anatexites in the central sector; iii) “transitional” mylonites, which are 



Microestruturas e tramas cristalográficas na zona de cisalhamento patos  

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 71 

located immediately south of the migmatites, and; iv) fine-grained mylonites to 

ultramylonites at the southernmost border (Figs. 2, 3). 

 The coarse-grained melt-bearing mylonites often contain irregular pods of 

monzogranitic leucosome (Fig. 3a) and feldspar clasts surrounded by elongated biotite flakes, 

which usually define a layered/banded structure (Fig. 3a). Centimetric quartz ribbons define 

an E-W subhorizontal stretching lineation. The interlayered leucosomes show evidence of 

solid-state deformation. Rotated K-feldspar porphyroclasts and fine-grained recrystallised 

quartz in pressure shadows at feldspar edges indicate dextral motion. The melt content 

progressively increases towards the contact with the anatexites, and the microstructure 

gradually changes from solid-state to magmatic. 

 The anatexites were mostly deformed in the magmatic state and have local solid-state 

overprints (Viegas et al. 2013). The nebulites and leucogranites are mainly isotropic with 

little or no mesoscale deformational features. The metatexites show an E-W preferred 

orientation of elongated K-feldspar and biotite grains (Fig. 3b). Varying degrees of partial 

melting result in complex field foliation geometries that are not always compatible with the 

shear zone’s strain field. However, the magnetic and crystallographic fabrics indicate that all 

of these structures resulted from dextral shear deformation in the Patos shear zone (Viegas et 

al. 2013). 

 South of the migmatites, the melt fractions gradually decrease, and the deformed 

rocks show a “transitional” character between migmatites and mylonites (Fig. 3c). Mafic 

phases become more common, while the leucosomes become increasingly sheared and less 

common. Medium-grained biotite-gneisses develop and usually display a preferred 

orientation of flattened phyllosilicates. Quartz is observed as dextrally-rotated sigmoids and 

as elongated rods that define a subhorizontal E-W lineation. 

 The southernmost part of the shear zone is composed of fine-grained (~ 20 µm) 

mylonites to ultramylonites that are mostly derived from high-temperature mylonites and 

local granite intrusions (Fig. 2). Mesoscale evidence of partial melting is lacking, and these 

rocks are mainly composed of fractured K-feldspar porphyroclasts that are immersed in a fine 

(5-15 µm) felsic matrix (Fig. 3d). Millimetre-scale quartz ribbons define the lineations, and 

rotated feldspar clasts show a dextral shear sense.

4. Results 

 

4.1. Microstructural data 

 

 The microstructures were investigated by conventional optical microscopy and SEM 

imagery. The mineralogical composition of the different rock types is constant throughout the 

zone and is formed of nearly equal proportions of K-feldspar + quartz + plagioclase with 

biotite as the main Fe-silicate. Accessory ilmenite, magnetite and zircon are common, and 

minor chlorite, epidote, muscovite and sericite can be observed towards the southern border.  

 

4.1.1. High-temperature melt-bearing mylonites 

 

 Quartz ribbons occur as rectangular grains with straight boundaries, subgrains and 

undulatory extinction (Figs. 4a, b). The subgrain boundaries are often oriented oblique to 

normal to the foliation. Polycrystalline aggregates of coarse equant grains (> 350 µm) display 



Microestruturas e tramas cristalográficas na zona de cisalhamento patos  

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 73 

sutured/serrated boundaries and migrating borders towards the adjacent phases (Fig. 4a). The 

quartz grains outside the ribbons are smaller (~ 100-200 µm) and have embayed/lobate 

boundaries with small bulges at quartz-quartz contacts (Fig. 4c, d). Internal subgrain 

boundaries remain oblique to normal to the foliation, and bulging structures are common 

(Figs. 4c, d). Late microcracks crosscut the coarse grains (Fig. 4d). 

 K-feldspar forms coarse (150-300 µm), rectangular to subelliptical porphyroclasts 

with straight boundaries (Figs. 4c, d). Fine-grained myrmekites mantle coarse anhedral clasts 

and may be associated with fine recrystallised quartz (<15 µm) that has been collected in the 

shear zones at grain boundaries (Figs. 4e, f). Undulatory extinction is common (Figs. 4e, f). 

Sets of late microcracks may be slightly oblique to the grain elongation (Fig. 4d). 

 The plagioclase (An35-38) is recrystallised as medium-sized anhedral crystals with 

straight boundaries in a local polygonal texture. Some of the boundaries are interfingered 

with fine quartz grains (~ 20-25 µm) and show lobate borders towards the quartz and K-

feldspar grains (Figs. 4c, d). Mechanical twins are locally bent, and late microcracks occur 

locally. 

  

4.1.2. Migmatites 

 

 Quartz often occurs as coarse anhedral grains up to 2 mm in size and as smaller 

crystallised grains ~ 70-200 µm in size. The coarse grains have straight boundaries and show 

undulatory extinction and subgrains. Medium- to fine-grained quartz grains occur widely as 

an interstitial phase that crystallised at quartz-Kfs-plagioclase boundaries (Figs. 5a, b, c). 

Fractures in the feldspar are preferential sites for the nucleation of newly crystallised quartz 

as “films” with bulging and pinning microstructures (Fig. 5b). 

 The K-feldspar forms coarse inequant porphyroclasts with pervasive crosshatch 

twinning and undulose to straight boundaries (Fig. 5a, c, d). Fine patches (~ 10-30 µm) of 

albite lamellae crosscut the porphyroclasts (Fig. 5d) oblique to normal to the mylonitic 

foliation. Dilatant fractures cut the porphyroclasts normal to the foliation and either cut 

across the entire grain or terminate within the grain. The cracks occur preferentially at 

cleavage planes or twin boundaries and may be filled by newly-crystallised quartz or fine 

albite grains. The boundaries between adjacent K-feldspar grains are preferential sites for 

myrmekite nucleation as small (<15 µm) films (Fig. 5a) or within fine rounded grains (Figs. 

5c).

 The plagioclase is mainly andesitic (An35-38) and ranges from 100 to 300 µm in size

may be locally filled by sericite.

4.1.3. Transitional mylonites 

 

 Coarse quartz grains (150-300 µm) have sutured/serrated boundaries, may form 

foliation-parallel ribbons that surround coarse K-feldspar porphyroclasts (Figs. 6a, b) and 

have oblique subgrain boundaries and undulatory extinction. The coarse grains may be 

locally associated with traces of melt that occur as fine crystals (<30 µm) at grain boundaries 

(arrows in Fig. 6a). The quartz may also be recrystallised as fine (50-100 µm) grains 

associated with micas (Fig. 6b) as well as polygonal mosaics of finer (<45 µm) grains with 

straight borders (Fig. 6e); these polycrystalline aggregates define mesoscale ribbons that are 

parallel to the mylonitic foliation. 

 The K-feldspar occurs either as rotated porphyroclasts (Figs. 6a, b) or as elongated 

augen (Figs. 6c, d). Fine grains (<20 µm) fill fractures and newly-formed millimetre-thick 

shear zones that developed both normal and parallel to the foliation (Figs. 6e, f). The fine-

grained K-feldspar appears to be strain free and is sometimes associated with fine 

recrystallised quartz. The microshear zones locally contain small amounts of low-grade 

hydrous minerals, such as chlorite and epidote.

4.1.4. Low-temperature mylonites 

  

 Quartz forms millimetre-scale (~ 30 µm) elongated ribbons and fine (<15 µm) 

recrystallised grains in the matrix. The ribbons usually have straight boundaries with 

rectangular subgrain walls that are normal to the foliation (Figs. 7a, d, e, f). Fine aggregates 

may be recrystallised as ribbons that are oblique to the foliation (Fig. 7e). The quartz in the 

matrix (~ 5 µm) is completely recrystallised and is associated with recrystallised K-feldspar, 

plagioclase and biotite. Microfaults displace the matrix material alongside the quartz bands 

(Fig. 7a).  

 K-feldspar (~ 100-200 µm) is immersed in the felsic matrix as anhedral grains or 

stretched porphyroclasts (Figs. 7b, c, d, e), which show undulatory extinction and are 

pervasively crosscut by fractures that extend throughout the entire grain. Fractures can occur 

as sets of oriented and equally-spaced cracks that transect the grains in “domino” 

configurations (Fig. 7b) and can also displace the porphyroclast with normal offsets that are 

filled by the matrix material (Fig. 7c). Fine trails of matrix minerals may also surround the 

porphyroclasts (Figs. 7b, c). The elongated porphyroclasts are strongly stretched in the 

foliation direction and show pinch-and-swell/boudinage structures with straight to curved 

boundaries (Fig. 7d). The stretching sometimes results in dilaceration of former 

porphyroclasts into discontinuous fine ribbons (Fig. 7d). 

 Plagioclase rarely occurs as porphyroclasts except for medium-grained (~ 100 µm) 

clasts that are crosscut by sets of equally-spaced fractures that are oriented in a domino 

arrangement (Fig. 7b). Fine-grained plagioclase (~ 5 µm) dominates the matrix. 

 

4.2. Crystallographic preferred orientations 

 

4.2.1. Methods 

 

 Representative samples of the Patos mylonites were chosen for EBSD analysis of 

quartz and feldspars. Each sample was cut in the XZ section of the strain ellipsoid and was 

polished to ensure a flat surface. The orientation measurements were performed in a JEOL 

JSM 5600 scanning electron microscope (SEM) that was equipped with an Oxford 

Instruments/HKL Nordlys EBSD detector at Géosciences Montpellier. The Channel 5 

Program (Oxford Instruments) was used for the data treatment. Samples were inserted into 

the microscope chamber at an angle of 70º relative to the electron beam and with a working

The acquisition step sizes ranged from 25 to 50 µm, and the orientation measurements were 

rotated into the geographical frame.

4.2.2. Lattice fabric results 

 

 The quartz [0001] axis in the melt-bearing mylonites displays well-defined 

concentrations in the centre of the diagram with symmetrical a-axis maxima in the periphery 

around Z and X (Fig. 8a). The increase in melt content towards the centre of the shear zone 

results in weak patterns and random crystallographic fabrics in the anatexites, which are 

marked by small [0001] axis point maxima close to Z and Y and a-axes that form isolated 

weak concentrations near Y (Fig. 8b). The transitional mylonites show a dispersion of [0001] 

axes along the YZ plane with maxima in Y and minor concentrations located between Y and 

Z. This pattern resembles a faint single-girdle in the NS direction (Fig. 8c). The a-axes are 

scattered through the periphery of the diagram with maxima in X, which is consistent with 

the orientation of the stretching lineations observed in the field. The low-temperature 

mylonites display strong [0001] axis concentrations in Z that spread to intermediary positions 

between Z and Y, while the a-axes are mainly concentrated in the periphery and form 

maxima around X (Fig. 8d).

 The K-feldspar in the melt-bearing mylonites displays maxima of (100) poles that are 

spread near the stretching lineation direction (X), but they also form girdles that split into two 

small maxima in the periphery close to X. The (010) poles are mainly concentrated close to 

Z, and the (001) poles show weak or no crystallographic preferred orientation (Fig. 9a, b). 

The migmatites display concentrations of K-feldspar (010) poles in Z and maxima of (100) 

poles close to X, i.e., in the lineation direction (Fig. 9c), which suggests activity of the 

commonly reported (010)[100] slip system (Schulmann et al. 1996; Martelat et al. 1999; 

Kruse et al. 2001). In the transitional mylonites, the (100) poles define maxima close to the 

stretching lineation, and the (010) poles form an asymmetrical girdle over the YZ plane with 

concentrations around Z (Fig. 10a). Near the contact with the low-temperature mylonites, the 

(100) poles display weak concentrations over Z, and the (010) poles form small (10-15º) 

angles with X, which suggests activity of the (100)[010] slip system (Fig. 10b; Ishii et al. 

2007). The fine-grained mylonites display evidence of activity on the (100)[001] and 

(010)[001] slip systems (Fig. 10c; Tullis 1983; Martelat et al. 1999; Menegon et al. 2008). 

 The plagioclase fabrics have (100) poles that form girdles parallel to the stretching 

lineation and maxima close to Y, which suggests activity of the (010)[100] and (010)[001] 

slip systems in the melt-bearing mylonites (Figs. 9a, b). The (010)[100] slip system is also 

observed in the migmatites as girdles of (100) poles in the lineation direction (Fig. 9c). In the 

transitional mylonites, the activated slip systems include (010)[100] and (100)[010], which is 

indicated by the (100) and (010) poles close to X, respectively (Figs. 10a, b). The fabrics in 

the low-temperature mylonites (Fig. 10c) are marked by (100) poles that are asymmetrically 

concentrated close to X, which suggests the contribution of the tentative (100)[001] slip 

system (Kruse et al. 2001). 

 

4.3. Titanium-in-Quartz Thermometry 

 

 The Ti content in the recrystallised quartz was measured according to the procedures 

described by Wark & Watson (2006). The method is based on the activity of TiO2 (aTiO2), 

which can be used as a strain geothermometer in deformed rocks. For rutile-saturated rocks, 

aTiO2 = 1. The Patos mylonites do not contain rutile, but an aTiO2 of 0.6 - 0.8 for crustal 

granitic mylonites is widely accepted in the literature (Wark & Watson 2006, Wark et al. 

2007). We consider an aTiO2 of 0.7 ± 0.2 for our samples, which is consistent with previous

work on mylonites in similar geological settings (Kohn & Northrup 2009; Menegon et al. 

2011).

4.4. U/Pb (SHRIMP) zircon geochronology 

 

4.4.1. Sampling and methods 

 

 We collected two samples of the felsic leucosomes (PTS, PAUG), one sample of a 

leucogranite (PA4) associated with the migmatites, and a sample of a mylonitic augen-granite 

(URT). Samples PTS, PAUG and PA4 come from the Espinho Branco anatexite (Viegas et 

al. 2013), while sample URT comes from the Urtiga granite, which is located in the southern 

margin of the Patos shear zone (location in Fig. 2). Samples PTS and PAUG comprise 

medium-grained K-feldspar, quartz, plagioclase and biotite in a granular texture with feldspar 

clasts that are surrounded by a faint shape-preferred orientation of biotite flakes. Sample PA4 

is an equigranular biotite-leucogranite with irregular to diffuse contacts with diatexite. The 



Microestruturas e tramas cristalográficas na zona de cisalhamento patos  

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 83 

augen mylonite (sample URT) is fine-grained and contains equal proportions of K-feldspar, 

quartz and plagioclase that define a banded structure. 

 The zircon grains from all of the samples were handpicked after standard crushing 

and separation. The clearest euhedral to subhedral grains were selected and mounted in epoxy 

with chips of TEMORA 1 reference zircon (206Pb/238U = 416.78 ± 0.33 Ma; Black et al. 

2004), sectioned approximately in half and polished. Reflected and transmitted light 

photomicrographs and cathodoluminescence (CL) SEM images were obtained for all of the 

grains. The analyses of the U-Th-Pb elements were conducted at the SHRIMP IIe laboratory 

of the Centro de Pesquisas Geocronológicas at the University of São Paulo. The isotopic data 

were collected in sets of five scans throughout the masses, and the TEMORA standard was 

measured after four unknown analyses. The abundances of U, Th and Pb, and the Pb isotopic 

ratios, were normalised using the SL13 zircon standard (U = 238 ppm). Common Pb was 

corrected using the measured 204Pb and assuming the appropriate model of Pb composition 

from Stacey and Kramers (1975). The data reduction was performed using the SQUID 1.06 

Excel macro (Ludwig 2000), and the statistical assessments were calculated using the 

geochronological ISOPLOT software of Ludwig (2003). The data are reported in Table 2 and 

are plotted on a Wetherill U-Pb concordia diagram. The uncertainties in the isotopic ratios 

and the ages are reported at the 1? level, and the weighted mean ages are reported as 95% 

confidence limits. 

 

4.4.2. Zircon microstructures 

 

 The zircons from the leucosomes and the leucogranite are morphologically similar. 

The grain sizes range from 50 to 400 µm in length, but the zircons from sample PTS reach 

300 µm in length. Axial ratios (long/short dimensions) between 2:1 and 4:1 are typical for all 

of the grains. 

 The crystals are euhedral to subhedral and are mostly colourless and inclusion free. 

CL imaging shows typical inner cores that display discrete fine-scale oscillatory zoning, 

which is interpreted to reflect magmatic growth (Fig. 11). Most of the cores are surrounded 

by homogeneous bright luminescent overgrowths (Fig. 11a, b, c). In some of the zircons, 

these overgrowths transgress the darker luminescent inherited cores (Fig. 11a, b). In other 

cases, the overgrowths are epitaxial and nearly continuous, and the cores preserve the 

magmatic prismatic shape (Fig. 11c). We interpret the overgrowths as having been produced

during a high temperature metamorphic event. The analysis of cores with oscillatory zoning 

and the respective overgrowths showed that they crystallised at distinct time periods. 

  

 
 

 Most of the zircons from sample URT (Fig. 11d) are broken with abundant internal 

fracturing. However, some preserved crystals display subhedral to euhedral shapes with grain 

sizes ranging from 50 to 300 µm in length and axial ratios from 1.4:1 to 2.7:1. CL imaging 

highlights the intense internal fracturing that sometimes forms a radial pattern (Fig. 11d). 

Bright luminescent inclusions are common and are normally aligned with crystal faces. Some 

zircons preserve oscillatory zoning, which indicates magmatic growth (Fig. 11d). 

Overgrowths were not detected. The ion-microprobe analysis was therefore focused on the 

more homogenous domains as far as possible from the fracture traces. Some of the zircons 

are porous and are characterised by abundant fine inclusions. These altered zones were not 

analysed because they probably represent dissolution and precipitation of new phases due to 

metamorphic fluid percolation (Hay & Dempster 2009).

4.4.3. Results 

 

 Twelve zircons from sample PTS were investigated and led to fifteen analyses of 

cores and their respective zircon overgrowths. The data define a discordia line with an upper 

intercept age at 2195 ± 13 Ma (Fig. 12a). Four concordant analyses (#2.2, #5.2, #6.2 and 

#9.2) fix the lower intercept age at 558 ± 21 Ma. The upper intercept is interpreted to date the 

crystallisation of the protolith, while the lower intercept represents the time of the thermal 

disturbance that formed the zircon overgrowths (Mezger and Krogstad 1997). 

 The analyses of the inner zircon cores of sample PAUG align in a discordia. After 

removing two reverse ages (#5.1, #10.1) and three discordant zircons (#9.2, #6.2b, #13.3), the 

remaining data define an upper intercept age of 2201 ± 12 Ma (Fig. 12b). Conversely, ten 

concordant zircon overgrowths cluster to yield a mean age of 552 ± 11 Ma (1?, MSWD = 

0.25). Furthermore, the combined analyses define a lower intercept age of 562 ± 12 Ma (Fig.

5. Discussion 

 

5.1. High-temperature deformation mechanisms and age of migmatisation  

 

 The sutured/lobate high-energy grain boundaries and subgrain walls that are normal to 

the coarse ribbons in the quartz, the myrmekite that replaces K-feldspar and the 

recrystallisation of plagioclase indicate deformation in the melt-bearing mylonites by high-

temperature dislocation creep (Passchier & Trouw 1996; Rosenberg & Berger 2001). Melt is 

observed mainly at interstitial grain boundaries and phase mixing distributions between 

quartz and feldspars (Fig. 4c, d, e). These structures are evidence of synkinematic melting 

and enhanced diffusional processes such as grain boundary migration (GBM), as exemplified 

by serrated quartz boundaries with small bulges at like-like (same phase) contacts (Nicolas & 

Poirier 1976; Vernon 2000; Rosenberg 2001; Sawyer 2010). Further evidence for high 

temperature conditions is provided by the activity of the prism<a> slip system in quartz (> 

500ºC; Schmid & Casey 1986) and the activation of the (010)[001] and (010)[100] slip 

systems in plagioclase (Ji & Mainprice 1988; Egydio-Silva et al. 2002).

heterogêneas 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

88 

 The microstructure in the migmatites is mainly magmatic with interstitial melt films 

at grain boundaries and microcracks in K-feldspar (Fig. 5). In addition, the presence of fine-

grained strain-free quartz and the occurrence of myrmekite suggest deformation mainly by 

granular flow with a limited contribution of plastic strain (Vernon 2000; Rosenberg 2001; 

Sawyer 2001). The quartz CPOs display no visible preferred orientation (Fig. 8b), but the 

feldspars show activity of the (010)[100] slip system (Fig. 9c). Taken together, these data 

indicate that melt-enhanced diffusion played an important part in the deformation of the 

migmatites and prevented the development of a crystallographic preferred orientation in the 

quartz due to crystallisation from the melt. On the other hand, the formation of a CPO in the 

feldspars might be attributed to oriented crystal growth during synmagmatic shearing 

(Tommasi et al. 1994; Garlick & Gromet 2004; Hasalová et al. 2008). 

 High temperature conditions are also recorded in zircon crystals from the migmatites, 

which usually have cores with fine magmatic oscillatory zoning enveloped by late 

homogeneously recrystallised zircon rims. Anatectic zircon can be formed by several 

different processes, such as dissolution-precipitation of pre-existing grains, breakdown of Zr-

bearing phases (e.g., biotite and monazite) and crystallisation from externally-derived Zr-

bearing fluids and melts (Rubatto et al. 2001; Andersson et al. 2002; Flowerdew et al. 2006). 

Nevertheless, irrespective of (re)crystallisation processes, zircon formation temperatures 

usually range from 850°C to 600°C and vary with the water content (Harley et al. 2007). The 
207Pb/238U ages of the zircon cores define an upper intercept at ~ 2.200 Ma, which indicates 

that the migmatite derived from partial melting of an older Palaeoproterozoic basement. In 

contrast, the homogeneous regions surrounding the inherited cores are Neoproterozoic and 

correspond to the melting event. The recrystallised zircons yielded lower intercept ages that 

are marked by nearly concordant analysis in the range of 558 - 562 Ma but have a relatively 

high analytical error. However, a leucogranite with diffuse to lobate contacts with the host 

migmatite provided a well-constrained lower intercept at 568 ± 10 Ma (MSWD = 2.2) and a 

mean age of 566 ± 5 Ma (MSWD = 1.3, 2? level). Hence, we consider the 565 - 568 Ma age 

range to be the best estimate for the crystallisation of the leucogranite. Field evidence 

suggests that the leucogranite was emplaced while the host rock was still molten, thus 

providing the age of the synkinematic melting at the Patos shear zone. 

 

 

 



Microestruturas e tramas cristalográficas na zona de cisalhamento patos  

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 89 

5.2. Transition from high-temperature to low-temperature mylonites 

 

 The progressive grain size reduction at medium- to low-temperatures that is observed 

in the transitional mylonites indicates that these rocks may mark a transient stage between 

high- and low-grade microstructures. Polygonal flattened or stretched quartz aggregates in 

the foliation result from subgrain rotation recrystallisation (Fig. 6e; Passchier & Trouw 

1996). In the K-feldspar, elongated clasts, microcracks that crosscut porphyroclasts, often in 

“domino” arrangements (Fig. 6f), and the widespread occurrence of recrystallised grains as 

fine trails that fill fractures indicate the contribution of pressure solution and/or grain 

boundary sliding mechanisms (Tullis 1983; Hasalová et al. 2008; Menegon et al. 2008). 

 The quartz fabrics suggest the activity of prism<a> and rhomb<a+c> slip systems, 

which are typical of high-temperature deformation at increasing strain rates (Stipp et al. 

2002). The feldspar CPOs record the activity of both the (010)[100] and (100)[010] slip 

systems (Figs. 10a, b). The activity of the (100)[010] slip system has been reported in granitic 

ultramylonites that deformed mainly via microfracturing and solution-precipitation creep in 

the Ryoke metamorphic belt (Ishii et al. 2007). Based on the lack of homogeneous phase 

mixing, these authors assumed that grain boundary sliding was not the dominant deformation 

mechanism responsible for the formation of feldspar CPO. In the transitional mylonites from 

the Patos shear zone, the fine-grained (<10 µm) recrystallised feldspars that fill fractures 

may have resulted from dissolution-precipitation processes (Wintsch & Yi 2002; Berger & 

Stunitz 1996). In addition, phase mixing is observed between quartz and feldspar in these 

dilatational sites, which suggests the involvement of grain boundary sliding (GBS) at upper 

greenschist/lower-amphibolite facies conditions (~ 500ºC), which was corroborated by the 

Ti-in-quartz measurements (section 4.3). The fact that low-grade mineral assemblages are 

locally observed indicates that hydrothermal fluids may have had a limited influence on the 

dissolution-precipitation processes at the southern border of the Patos shear zone. 

 

5.3. Low-temperature mylonitisation 

 

 The fine-grained mylonites to ultramylonites have a homogeneously-mixed felsic 

matrix that contains highly-deformed K-feldspar porphyroclasts and quartz-rich bands (Fig. 

7). The peak temperatures of ~ 490ºC that were calculated from the Ti contents of quartz 

indicate that this fine-grained mylonitic zone was deformed at upper greenschist facies 

conditions. The fine-grained recrystallised quartz grains (<15 µm) contain straight

heterogêneas 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

90 

boundaries and display undulatory extinction, which suggests deformation mainly by 

dislocation creep (Passchier & Trouw 1996). The K-feldspar porphyroclasts are crosscut by 

fractures and are sometimes stretched in the foliation direction (Fig. 7d), which may indicate 

crystal plastic deformation processes such as dislocation creep (FitzGerald & Stunitz 1993); 

the mixture of K-feldspar with other minerals in the matrix suggests a contribution of grain 

boundary sliding through homogeneous phase-mixing during high-strain deformation (Tullis 

1983). 

 The quartz CPOs that have concentrations between Z and Y indicate a progressive 

change from prism to rhomb planes activity at increasing strain conditions (Stipp et al. 2002). 

The development of feldspar CPOs suggests that recrystallisation was mainly attained by 

grain boundary sliding that was accommodated by dislocation creep; GBS is especially 

important in fine grains and can develop CPOs in feldspar grains (Tullis 1983). Moreover, 

the phase mixing that is widely observed in the matrix material also indicates that high-strain 

rates were achieved by a combination of crystal plastic processes at low-temperature 

conditions, probably in the presence of residual hydrothermal fluids (FitzGerald & Stunitz 

1993; Ishii et al. 2007; Menegon et al. 2008). 

  

5.3. Strain localisation and regional implications  

  

 The high-temperature mylonites of the Patos shear zone and the Seridó 

metasedimentary belt form a branched system that is characterised by a continuous foliation 

trend from E-W to NE-SW and by zones of partially molten rocks (Corsini et al. 1991). U-Pb 

(SHRIMP) zircon ages of ~ 575 Ma in the Acari granite and the Santa Luzia diatexite 

precisely constrain the syntectonic magmatism and the main high-temperature/low-pressure 

metamorphism in the Seridó belt (Archanjo et al. 2013). The high-temperature event in the 

Patos shear zone appears to be younger (565-568 Ma) than that in the Seridó belt. 

Alternatively, the lower intercept age of ~ 545 Ma recorded in the zircons from sample URT 

records upper greenschist facies reactivation at the southern border. These data suggest that 

the high- and low-temperature mylonitic processes are diachronic and occurred at distinct 

time intervals within the shear zone. 

 The main HT/LP metamorphism observed in the Seridó belt is coeval with 

widespread amphibolite facies mylonitisation and the emplacement of partially molten rocks 

within the Patos-Seridó shear system, which is suggested by their magnetic fabrics that are 



Microestruturas e tramas cristalográficas na zona de cisalhamento patos  

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 91 

consistent with the regional strain field (Santa Luzia and Espinho Branco anatexites, Fig. 2; 

Archanjo et al. 2013; Viegas et al. 2013). Partial melting induced weakening of the quartz 

fabrics, while the feldspars show well-defined CPOs due to grain growth during magmatic 

flow. These patterns indicate the partitioning of deformation into solid-state flow in the HT 

mylonites and granular flow in the migmatites. The presence of migmatites at the intersection 

between the Patos shear zone and the Seridó belt suggests that the curvature of the mylonitic 

fabric from E-W to NE-SW might have been facilitated by the distribution of the melting 

zones, which would act as weak layers of strain localisation at high temperatures (Rosenberg 

& Handy 2005). 

 In contrast, the melt-absent shear localisation along the southern border of the fault 

occurred at lower temperatures (~ 490ºC). This event partially reworked the structures of the 

Espinho Branco anatexite and is consistent with the younger age calculated from zircons of a 

sheared granite (now an augen-gneiss) that is hosted in fine-grained mylonites and 

phyllonites. The quartz CPOs that spread between Z and Y indicate the activity of dislocation 

creep at high strain rates. On the other hand, the feldspars deformed mainly by solution-

precipitation creep and grain boundary sliding, as indicated by recrystallisation, phase 

mixing, CPOs and the localised presence of low-temperature mineral assemblages that are 

probably associated with hydrothermal fluid percolation. 

 These observations suggest that the mylonitisation at the southern margin of the shear 

zone represents a second-stage reactivation process that is marked by further localisation of 

deformation within narrow zones. Because the greenschist-facies mylonites form the northern 

limit of the metasedimentary rocks and variably deformed granites of the Cachoeirinha belt 

(Archanjo et al. 2008), this corridor acted as a preferential layer that accommodated 

deformation due to the rheological heterogeneities between the two geological domains. 

  The tectonic reactivations observed in the Patos shear zone have also been 

documented in other shear domains of the Borborema Province (e.g., Davison et al. 1995; 

Neves et al. 2000; Vauchez & Egydio-Silva 1992; Hollanda et al. 2010). For instance, fine 

mylonites and ultramylonites from the dextral transcurrent Coxixola shear zone (Fig. 1) 

overprinted older basement structures for hundreds of kilometres in the E-W direction 

(Hollanda et al. 2010). Related granite plutons and dikes constrain the movement of the 

Coxixola mylonites between 548 and 533 Ma. Furthermore, late shear reactivation in the 

Seridó belt appeared to control the emplacement of Li-Be bearing pegmatites and Au 

mineralisations that are hosted in quartz veins (Baumgartner et al. 2006; Araújo et al. 2005). 

Available 40Ar/39Ar biotite and muscovite ages in the Patos, Coxixola and Seridó domains

provide cooling ages between 545 and 500 Ma, which are mainly attributed to differential 

regional uplift and final exhumation in the Late Cambrian (Corsini et al. 1998; Araújo et al. 

2005; Hollanda et al. 2010).  

 

6. Conclusions 

 

 Microstructures, CPOs and U/Pb (SHRIMP) zircon ages indicate a diachronic, short-

lived (~ 20 Ma) evolution composed of two distinct events in a midcrustal transcurrent shear 

zone. The northern high-temperature border is coupled with synkinematic anatexis and is 

associated with the main HT/LP metamorphism that is recorded in the Seridó belt. Such high-

temperature conditions enhanced the strain distribution and localised partial melting at the 

Patos-Seridó boundary. Alternatively, reactivation in the southern sector indicates that melt-

absent solid-state creep was active at least until the early Cambrian. 

 These results suggest that the heterogeneous evolution of the Patos shear zone 

occurred in a single kinematic strain field where distinct rheological conditions were present 

at different time intervals and ultimately led to different patterns of deformation within the 

strike-slip structure. The fact that the second-stage reactivation observed at the southern 

border correlates with the Coxixola fault suggests that the Cambrian tectono-magmatic 

activity is of regional extent and occurred in other shear zones across the Borborema 

Province. These late-stage low-temperature faults developed mainly along previously formed 

discontinuities at contrasting lithological boundaries, which are usually characterised by 

deformation at the semi-brittle to ductile transition.

CAPÍTULO 6 

 

CONCLUSÕES E CONSIDERAÇÕES FINAIS 

 

1. Síntese 

	
  
 Esta tese compreende o estudo das relações estruturais entre magmatismo e zonas de 

cisalhamento em níveis crustais intermediários. Com base na integração entre trabalhos de 

campo e o uso de técnicas multidisciplinares, tais como ASM, ARA, EBSD, U-Pb (SHRIMP) 

e TitaniQ, foi possível avaliar: i) os mecanismos de alojamento de migmatitos em contextos 

tectônicos distintos, ii) as relações estruturais entre o fluxo de material parcialmente fundido 

e o alojamento de granitos, iii) a correlação entre estruturas mesoscópicas e a trama interna 

em corpos migmatíticos, iv) o desenvolvimento de tramas magmáticas em anatexitos 

deformados em regimes transcorrentes, v) os processos de nucleação e localização da 

deformação em zonas de cisalhamento dúcteis, e vi) a cronologia de eventos magmáticos e 

deformacionais em um contexto de anatexia sincinemática. 

 As principais conclusões obtidas a partir do presente estudo são apresentadas a seguir. 

 

2. Metamorfismo de alto grau e fusão parcial na Faixa Seridó 

 

 O diatexito de Santa Luzia exibe uma trama magnética bem organizada e consistente 

com a orientação regional da Faixa Seridó. A diferença entre as foliações de campo, que 

configuram uma geometria dômica, e a trama magnética marcada por lineações concordantes 

ao eixo de elongação do domo, refletem a sensibilidade da ASM aos incrementos finais da 

deformação que afetou o migmatito, possivelmente após o alojamento. Estes dados sugerem 

que o domo de Santa Luzia foi alojado e deformado em um regime de fluxo viscoplástico, 

onde a trama interna reflete o padrão tectônico regional. 

A idade de 575 Ma obtida nos sobrecrescimentos metamórficos de zircões extraídos do 

leucossoma posiciona de forma precisa a fusão parcial no sistema de cisalhamento Patos-

Seridó, a qual correlaciona-se com a idade de alojamento do pluton de Acari (~ 577 Ma), 

localizado mais a norte. Adicionalmente, a trama magnética é concordante no domo de Santa 

Luzia e no granito Acari, sugerindo que a fusão parcial do embasamento e a colocação de 

granitos porfiríticos estão mecanicamente associados na Faixa Seridó. Por outro lado, as 



Mecanismos de deformação e cronologia de eventos na zona de cisalhamento Patos 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

98 

tramas circulares observadas no granito Totoró indicam que o mesmo é pré-cinemático em 

relação à deformação transcorrente do Seridó, o que é corroborado pela idade de ~ 595 Ma 

obtida em dioritos e granitos deste corpo plutônico.   

Dessa forma, os dados geocronológicos e estruturais permitem concluir que a atividade 

magmática observada na região de Santa Luzia teve início antes da deformação registrada na 

Faixa Seridó, sendo subsequentemente associada a metamorfismo das rochas do 

embasamento e fusão parcial na crosta intermediária, esta última conectada ao plutonismo 

granítico observado em níveis crustais mais rasos. 

 

3. Tramas migmatíticas e alojamento de magmas em regimes transcorrentes 

 

 A complexidade geométrica observada no anatexito Espinho Branco não é observada 

na orientação da trama magnética, a qual se mostra concordante ao campo deformacional da 

zona de cisalhamento Patos. Entretanto, as relações entre trama de campo e trama magnética 

não são diretas, especialmente em sítios onde as foliações de campo não são confiáveis e os 

valores de suscetibilidade são muito baixos. Nestes casos, o mapeamento da trama interna 

através da ASM pode levar a resultados não-conclusivos. 

 Nas amostras com suscetibilidades moderadas a altas (> 1.0 mSI), a magnetita é o 

mineral portador do sinal magnético e domina a anisotropia de suscetibilidade. A trama 

magnética exibe boa compatibilidade com foliações de campo e os eixos [001] de cristais de 

biotita alinham-se em concordância com as direções de k3 da ASM. Alternativamente, 

suscetibilidades baixas (<0.5 mSI) registram uma dispersão das direções de k1 e k3, 

evidenciando a presença de sub-tramas que influenciam a trama magnética. Com efeito, as 

tramas magnética e cristalográfica podem exibir direções contrastantes, e comumente não se 

correlacionam com geometrias de campo. Contudo, as direções de ARA permanecem 

consistentes com o padrão regional e registram a orientação geral da trama magnética no 

migmatito. 

 Este banco de dados sugere que a geometria complexa de anatexitos alojados em 

zonas de cisalhamento transcorrentes não é compatível com sua respectiva trama interna, a 

qual registra os incrementos finais da deformação cisalhante. A trama de ARA confirma o 

caráter ferromagnético do migmatito, dominado por magnetita, enquanto que  as tramas de 

biotita são concordantes com as direções de k3. Entretanto, suscetibilidades muito baixas (<

0.5 mSI) podem indicar a presença de sub-tramas definidas por silicatos ferromagnesianos e 

fases hidrotermais tardias, e.g. hematita, as quais seriam responsáveis pela diminuição dos 



Capítulo 6 – Conclusões e considerações finais 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 99 

valores de suscetibilidade, dispersão da trama magnética e o desenvolvimento de orientações 

preferenciais secundárias (Trindade et al. 2001; Just et al. 2004; Archanjo et al. 2009). 

 Dessa forma, pode-se concluir que a ASM é uma ferramenta útil para recuperar a 

trama interna de migmatitos alojados no interior de zonas de cisalhamento dúcteis, 

particularmente em rochas com suscetibilidades altas (> 1.0 mSI). Entretanto, baixos valores 

de suscetibilidade (<0.5 mSI) podem refletir a presença de sub-tramas caracterizadas pela 

interação de fases hidrotermais tardias com os minerais magnéticos, as quais promovem 

dispersão das orientações da ASM. Nesses casos, investigações complementares englobando 

ARA e OPCs devem ser empregadas com o objetivo de detectar sub-tramas e avaliar o 

significado dos dados de ASM. 

 

4.  Localização da deformação e reativação na zona de cisalhamento Patos 

 

 A história deformacional da zona de cisalhamento Patos evoluiu de forma diacrônica, 

com a borda norte registrando idades mais antigas que o setor sul. A idade de ~ 566 Ma 

obtida nos leucossomas do migmatito Espinho Branco é ligeiramente mais jovem que a idade 

do metamorfismo e fusão parcial registrados na Faixa Seridó (~ 575 Ma). Adicionalmente, os 

milonitos finos a ultramilonitos da borda sul registram idades em torno de 545 Ma. Estes 

dados sugerem que i) a zona de cisalhamento Patos registrou temperaturas altas por mais 

tempo durante a evolução do sistema, caracterizadas por uma prolongada atividade da fusão 

parcial, ou ii) o resfriamento se deu de forma mais rápida na faixa metassedimentar, 

possivelmente devido ao contraste litológico observado no contato entre augen-gnaisses do 

embasamento, o migmatito Santa Luzia e os metassedimentos da Faixa Seridó. 

 Dados termocronológicos obtidos pelo método 40Ar/39Ar em anfibólio e biotita 

indicam uma taxa de resfriamento lenta, em torno de 3-4ºC por ano, entre 540 e 500 Ma na 

zona de cisalhamento Patos (Corsini et al. 1998; Monié et al. 1997). Tais características 

sugerem que a nucleação da estrutura se deu em condições de alta temperatura, envolvendo 

fusão parcial, e possivelmente associada ao metamorfismo em fácies anfibolito registrado na 

Faixa Seridó. A presença de anatexitos favoreceu a localização da deformação na porção 

norte da estrutura, configurando uma zona de instabilidade reológica marcada pela curvatura 

geométrica e conexão entre a zona de cisalhamento e a faixa metassedimentar. Por outro 

lado, a borda sul evoluiu na ausência de magma e em condições de médio- a baixo-grau, 

como demonstrado pelas estimativas de temperatura calculadas pelo método TitaniQ 

(Capítulo 5). Estas condições metamórficas envolveram geração de milonitos finos a 



Mecanismos de deformação e cronologia de eventos na zona de cisalhamento Patos 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

100 

ultramilonitos a partir de recristalização extensiva e progressiva diminuição do tamanho dos  

grãos. 

 A localização da deformação em corredores de cisalhamento ao longo da margem sul 

da zona de cisalhamento Patos exibe semelhança com outras áreas da Província Borborema, 

como as zonas de cisalhamento Coxixola e Pernambuco (Hollanda et al. 2010; Neves & 

Mariano 1999). Nestas, transformações metamórficas de médio- a baixo-grau retrabalham 

rochas de alta-temperatura gerando faixas miloníticas intensamente deformadas. Estas zonas 

de cisalhamento possuem idades entre 548 e 533 Ma (Hollanda et al. 2010), concordantes 

com a idade de 545 Ma obtida nos ultramilonitos da zona de cisalhamento Patos. 

 Dessa forma, a reativação registrada na zona de cisalhamento Patos constitui um 

evento regional, ativo em outras áreas da Província Borborema durante a transição 

Neoproterozóico-Cambriano, e caracterizado pela atuação de mecanismos de deformação que 

incluem fluência de deslocações e fraturamento intracristalino. Estes mecanismos são 

observados nos corredores miloníticos relativamente retilíneos e pouco espessos, restritos à 

borda sul da estrutura, onde o contraste litológico inerente às condições de limite da zona 

favorece a acumulação da deformação e resulta em microestruturas geradas principalmente 

na faixa de transição reológica dúctil-rúptil. 

 

5. Considerações finais  

 

i) A ASM constitui uma ferramenta útil no mapeamento da trama interna de migmatitos 

alojados em sistemas de cisalhamento transpressivos. A trama interna do domo de Santa 

Luzia revela um alojamento controlado pelo cisalhamento dextral da Faixa Seridó, em 

concordância com o fluxo magmático em níveis crustais mais rasos, representado pelo 

granito Acari. Na zona de cisalhamento Patos, a geometria complexa dos leucossomas do 

migmatito Espinho Branco não é reproduzida em sua trama magnética, a qual se mostra bem 

organizada e consistente com a cinemática da zona de cisalhamento. 

 

ii) Investigações estruturais por meio de técnicas complementares, como a ARA e tramas 

cristalográficas, são particularmente úteis quando a trama de ASM exibe variações nos 

valores de suscetibilidade e direção magnética. Nestes casos, as OPCs fornecem informações 

importantes sobre as orientações preferenciais de eventuais sub-tramas formadas por fases 

minerais distintas (silicatos, óxidos), enquanto que a ARA revela o padrão direcional das 

fases ferromagnéticas. Dada a complexidade da geometria de campo e a heterogeneidade da 



Capítulo 6 – Conclusões e considerações finais 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 101 

percentagem de fusão parcial observada em rochas parcialmente fundidas, a aplicação 

integrada das referidas técnicas, em conjunto com trabalhos de campo detalhados, se faz 

fundamental no estudo dos mecanismos de migração e transporte de magmas ao longo da 

crosta intermediária. 

 

iii) A investigação cronológica do magmatismo na região do Seridó sugere que a fusão 

parcial é sincrônica ao plutonismo granítico observado em níveis crustais mais rasos. Com 

efeito, as tramas magnéticas concordantes em migmatitos e granitos corroboram essa 

hipótese. Análises geoquímicas complementares constituem o próximo passo na investigação 

geológica destas rochas; tais dados serão importantes na caracterização tipológica do 

magmatismo e identificação de suas fontes, bem como no refinamento da correlação entre 

rochas parcialmente fundidas e granitoides na crosta continental intermediária-superior. 

 

iv) A presença de microestruturas e mecanismos de deformação contrastantes nas bordas 

norte e sul da zona de cisalhamento Patos, em associação com as idades obtidas em zircões 

de leucossomas na borda norte, milonitos na borda sul e as estimativas de temperatura obtidas 

por meio do método TitaniQ, sugerem que a nucleação da estrutura se deu em condições de 

alta temperatura, na presença de fusão parcial, por volta de 565 Ma. Após esse primeiro 

evento, uma reativação subsequente em 545 Ma retrabalhou os milonitos grossos e 

migmatitos gerando milonitos finos a ultramilonitos em temperaturas intermediárias a baixas, 

definindo faixas miloníticas concentradas na borda sul. 

 

v) A localização da deformação de médio- a baixo-grau na porção sul da estrutura se deve ao 

contraste litológico entre a zona de cisalhamento Patos e a Zona Transversal, a qual é 

formada por metapelitos e granitos fracamente deformados. Estas diferenças litológicas, não-

observáveis na borda norte da estrutura, provavelmente contribuíram para o caráter dúctil-

rúptil da reativação observada na borda sul da zona de cisalhamento Patos. 

 

vi) A idade dos eventos de magmatismo, metamorfismo e fusão parcial registrados a norte da 

zona de cisalhamento Patos (~ 575 Ma), quando comparados com idades dos plutons mais 

antigos alojados no domínio a sul da estrutura, conhecido como Zona Transversal (~ 630-610 

Ma), corroboram a hipótese de a zona de cisalhamento Patos representar um limite crustal 

dividindo terrenos com evoluções geológicas distintas (Vauchez et al. 1995). Com efeito, o 

batólito Teixeira, localizado no contato sul da estrutura, exibe tramas obliquas a normais à 



Mecanismos de deformação e cronologia de eventos na zona de cisalhamento Patos 

	
  

Tese de doutorado                                                                                                                              L. G. F. Viegas 
	
  

102 

orientação do cinturão de cisalhamento, e possui uma idade de cristalização em torno de 590 

Ma, associada a um estágio inicial de alojamento de magmas anterior ao desenvolvimento de 

estruturas transcorrentes (Archanjo et al. 2008; Neves et al. 2006). Os dados obtidos no 

presente trabalho indicam que a nucleação e desenvolvimento da zona de cisalhamento Patos 

se deu a partir de 565 Ma. Dessa forma, esta zona de cisalhamento representa uma estrutura 

pós-colisional, nucleada no intervalo 570-560 Ma, e gerada após a colagem de blocos crustais 

ao final do Neoproterozóico, possivelmente como resultado da transferência progressiva de 

esforços colisionais em deslocamentos transcorrentes. 

 

vii) A reativação tardia observada na zona de cisalhamento Patos, datada em 545 Ma, exibe 

características similares com a deformação observada em outras zonas de cisalhamento da 

Província Borborema (e.g. Coxixola, Pernambuco), as quais estão associadas à intrusão de 

granitoides máficos e félsicos na transição Neoproterozóico-Cambriano. Portanto, pode-se 

concluir que a deformação de baixo-grau observada na zona de cisalhamento Patos constitui 

um evento de caráter regional, observado em outras áreas da Província Borborema, e 

possivelmente associado à colisões tardias na margem oeste do Gondwana (Hollanda et al. 

2010).
